hints_html: How can we use our solution from part(a) and the initial conditions to find the true particular solution?
hints_raw: How can we use our solution from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2011/Question_B2_(a)|part(a)]] and the initial conditions to find the true particular solution?
question: B 02 (b)
sols_html:
Recall from part (a) that we figured out that the general solution was

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}(t)=c_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\exp(-t) + c_2 \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\exp(-2t).\end{aligned}\]

With the initial condition

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}(0)= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix},\end{aligned}\]

we can find the constants \(c_1\) and \(c_2\) for this particular problem. Plugging in the initial condition we get,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}(0)=c_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\exp(0) + c_2 \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\exp(0)= \begin{bmatrix} c_1+2c_2\\ 2c_1+3c_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we conclude that,

\[\begin{aligned} \left\{\begin{aligned} c_1+2c_2&=1\\ 2c_1+3c_2&=1 \end{aligned}\right.\end{aligned}\]

which has solution, \(c_1=-1\) and \(c_2=1\). Therefore the solution to this problem with initial condition

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}(0)= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}(t)=- \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\exp(-t) + \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\exp(-2t).\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Recall from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2011/Question_B2_(a)|part (a)]] that we figured out that the general solution was

:<math>
\mathbf{y}(t)=c_1
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2
\end{bmatrix}\exp(-t)
+ c_2
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3
\end{bmatrix}\exp(-2t).
</math>

With the initial condition

:<math>
\mathbf{y}(0)=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix},
</math>

we can find the constants <math>c_1</math> and <math>c_2</math> for this particular problem.  Plugging in the initial condition we get,

:<math>
\mathbf{y}(0)=c_1
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2
\end{bmatrix}\exp(0)
+ c_2
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3
\end{bmatrix}\exp(0)=
\begin{bmatrix}
c_1+2c_2\\
2c_1+3c_2
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

Therefore we conclude that,

:<math>
\left\{\begin{align}
c_1+2c_2&=1\\
2c_1+3c_2&=1
\end{align}\right.
</math>

which has solution, <math>c_1=-1</math> and <math>c_2=1</math>.  Therefore the solution to this problem with initial condition

:<math>
\mathbf{y}(0)=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

is

:<math>
\mathbf{y}(t)=-
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2
\end{bmatrix}\exp(-t)
+ 
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3
\end{bmatrix}\exp(-2t).
</math>
statement_html:
Consider the differential equation system

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}'=A\mathbf{y}\end{aligned}\]

where A has eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=-1\) and \(\lambda_2=-2\) with corresponding eigenvectors

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{k}_1&= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2 \end{bmatrix},\qquad \mathbf{k}_2&= \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Find the solution that matches the initial conditions

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}(0)= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Consider the differential equation system

:<math>
\mathbf{y}'=A\mathbf{y}
</math>

where A has eigenvalues <math>\lambda_1=-1</math> and <math>\lambda_2=-2</math> with corresponding eigenvectors

:<math>
\begin{align}
\mathbf{k}_1&=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2
\end{bmatrix},\qquad
\mathbf{k}_2&=
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3
\end{bmatrix}.
\end{align}
</math>

Find the solution that matches the initial conditions

:<math>
\mathbf{y}(0)=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>
